texts.shortText: One of the more distinctive species in this diverse and confusing genus, which includes a number of very variable local species. The colony is thin and encrusting and forms meandering ‘ladders’ of paired zooids that lie on either side of a central cloacal (exhalent) channel that has few, hardly–visible opening. The chains of zooids may branch and although variable in colour are most commonly pink or red, the colour being concentrated within the zooids, the matrix of the tunic being relatively transparent.
Zooids about 2 mm, but colonies up to about 100 mm long.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape only, from about Cape Peninsula to Knysna.
Fairly common almost always under boulders and in similar shaded habitats. Little else is know about biology.

All ascidians are filter-feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.

Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

The ladder-like arrangement of the zooids in long parallel chains on either side of the cloacal channel is fairly distinctive. Still can be confused with various other Botryllus species though and the detailed taxonomy of this and other members of the group remain confused (see Monniot reference below).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 77).
